ELIZABETH HERTEL
GOVERNOR DIRECTOR
October 13, 2025
Andrea Melendrez
ADRIAN GROUP HOME
190 PLEASANT KNOLL DR,
ADRIAN, MI, 49221-1220
Re: License #: CI460403164
SI #: 2025SIC0001000
Dear Andrea Melendrez:
Attached is the Special Investigation Report for the above referenced facility. Due to the
violations identified in the report, a corrective action plan is required. The corrective action
plan must be completed and routed in CWLM. If you desire technical assistance in
addressing these issues, please feel free to contact me. Failure to submit an acceptable
corrective action plan will result in disciplinary action.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact Samantha Way the area manager at 517-243-9743.
Sincerely,
Paul Fatato, Licensing Consultant
enclosure
P.O. BOX 30650 • LANSING, MICHIGAN 48909
www.michigan.gov • (517) 335-1980

MICHIGAN DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
DIVISION OF CHILD WELFARE LICENSING
SPECIAL INVESTIGATION REPORT
I. IDENTIFYING INFORMATION
Special Investigation #: 2025SIC0001000
Special Investigation Intake Date: 09/08/2025
License #: CI460403164
Licensee Group Organization: LHS Family and Youth Services
Licensee Designee: Catherine Zawisza
Chief Administrator: Andrea Melendrez
Agency Name: ADRIAN GROUP HOME
Agency Address: 190 PLEASANT KNOLL DR
ADRIAN, MI 49221-1220
License Status: Regular
License Expiration Date: 02/12/2026
Capacity: 10

III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4126
Section Sufficiency of staff.
Description (1) The licensee shall have a sufficient number of administrative,
supervisory, social service, direct care, and other staff on duty to
perform the prescribed functions required by these administrative
rules and in the agency's program statement and to provide for the
continual needs, protection, and supervision of residents
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation An unknown youth has been coming into Youth A's room at night.
Youth A and this unknown minor have been going to the living
room to kiss each other. Youth A and this unknown youth have
also been touching each other inappropriately on an unknown
location on their bodies. No penetration has been reported but this
has occurred on more than one occasion. Youth A has limited
cognition and has special education needs. It is unknown if staff
members at the group home are aware of this occurring.
Investigation Complainant was interviewed via phone on 9/4/2025. She
reported having no further information to provide about the
incident. She reported Youth A has been sleeping at school after
asking Youth A about sleeping at night, Youth A disclosed the
information of someone touching Youth A at night. Youth A did not
disclose any time frames for the alleged touching and was unable
to identify the staff who were in the living room when Youth A went
into the living room and kissed another youth.
Youth A was interviewed at the school on 9/10/2025. Youth A
reported not knowing who is sneaking into Youth A’s room at night
but described this person as a male who is short. Youth A
reported knowing it was a male because Youth A stated it was a
“brother” and there are “two brothers” (Youth C is tall and Youth F
is short) in the program. Youth A denied kissing anyone in the
program nor sneaking out of Youth A’s room. Youth A reported
staff are always in the hallway and keep an eye on Youth A.
Administrator was interviewed face to face at the facility on
9/10/2025. She reported Youth A is very limited in Youth A’s ability
to communicate and will use a tablet to communicate. She
reported a belief that Youth A does not understand the process
staff use at night for supervision. Administrator reported Youth A is
gone almost every weekend for scheduled family visits and
because of the bedroom doors remaining open at night and staff
sitting in the hallway, the allegations would be impossible. She
2

reported there are 5 bedrooms with Youth A sharing a bedroom
with Youth B. The other four youth (Youth C, Youth D, Youth E,
and Youth F have their own bedrooms). Administrator was asked
about the reason Youth A shares a bedroom with Youth D and
she reported Youth D is the newest youth in the program (no
history of sexually acting out) and the other youth (Youth B, Youth
C, Youth E, and Youth F) are very territorial and would not accept
another youth in their rooms. Another aspect is Youth A being
gone on home visits often. She reported there is camera footage
of the hallway and this will be reviewed. Administrator will develop
a safety plan that involves 3rd shift staff sitting outside of the
doorway to the room with Youth A and Youth D. Administrator
was interviewed again via video call on 9/26/2025. She
reported having a staff meeting and going over the 2-video
recordings (8/26/25 and 9/4/25) reviewed for this investigation.
She reported the staff observed in the videos agreed with the
findings that they were not conducting room checks as required.
She reported the staff had no justification for their actions and
were very apologetic. She reported Supervisor is now making
nightly in person checks on the 3rd shift staff.
Staff 1 was interviewed face to face at the facility on
9/10/2025. She reported having worked all three shifts in the past
and primarily 2nd shift at this time. She reported never witnessing a
youth getting up in the night unless they use the restroom or get a
drink of water.
Staff 2 was interviewed face to face at the facility on
9/10/2025. She reported working 3rd shift and denied that the
allegations could be accurate. She reported staff are always in the
hallway and any youth that comes out of their room or gets up
from their bed (hearing a youth get up) without staff being aware
would not happen. She reported never observing Youth A get out
of bed and the small male youth (Youth F) get out of bed or wake
up during the night.
Staff 3 was interviewed face to face at the facility on
9/10/2025. She reported working 3rd shift and gave the same
report as Staff 2. She reported hearing some of the youth talk in
their sleep but generally they never get out of bed because of the
“medication they are taking” and denied ever witnessing another
youth going into Youth A’s bedroom.
Staff 4 was interviewed face to face at the facility on
9/10/2025. He reported working 2nd shift, and the youth go to bed
towards the end of his shift. He reported staff always have eyes
3

on the hallway after the youth go to bed and conduct documented
room checks when the youth are down for bedtime. He reported
having no issues with Youth A and Youth D sharing a bedroom
because he will sit outside of the room until they fall asleep and
continue to do room checks until the end of the shift. He reported
generally there are 2 to 4 staff on the 2nd shift.
Staff 5 was interviewed face to face at the facility on
9/10/2025. He reported working 2nd shift and gave the same report
as Staff 4. He reported the youth tend to be heavy sleepers
because of the medication they are taking.
Staff 6 was interviewed face to face at the facility on
9/10/2025. She reported working 2nd shift and gave the same
report as other staff interviewed. She reported checking on any
noise she might hear down the hallway or from a bedroom. She
reported Youth A is gone often from visits with parents and the
last visit was from Thursday to Monday over the Labor Day
Holiday.
Youth D was interviewed video call on 9/26/2025. She reported
sharing a room with Youth A since entering the program
approximately 1 month ago. She reported not wanting to share a
room because she want’s her own room. Youth D reported staff sit
outside of the bedroom and will also walk around the hallway
checking on youth. Youth D denied anyone comes into the room
during the night and Youth D reported feeling safe at the facility.
Youth D also reported getting up to use the bathroom at night and
seeing staff in the hallway.
Youth F was interviewed video call on 9/26/2025. Youth F
reported a bedtime of 8:00 pm and reported staff check on Youth
F during the night. Youth F reported letting staff know if Youth F
needs to use the bathroom and reported staff sitting in the hallway
at night. Youth F denied going into any other youth’s bedroom.
Documents Reviewed:
Genacross Lutheran Services Staffing Requirements and
Supervision dated 11/13/24. This document outlines the required
supervision of youth in the program. The following is the policy:
• Genacross will ensure a minimum staffing ratio of one staff
to two clients during wake hours for any home in the State of
Michigan.
• Genacross will ensure a minimum staffing ratio of two staff
to ten clients during sleeping hours in the State of Michigan.
4

• Genacross will ensure a minimum staffing ratio of one staff
to ten clients during awake and sleeping hours in the State
in Ohio.
• Childcare staff will provide supervision as specified in the
clients’ service plan. It should be noted that an email
notification is made to all staff should any client be on a level
system due to ongoing concerns.
o If the treatment team determines that a youth needs
placed on a behavioral level, specific parameters are
determined based on the youth and the reason for the
level. Specific supervision guidelines will be posted in
the home for staff to review as well as in our electronic
system. Supervision guidelines will be posted in the
home for staff reference.
o If a clinician determines that a youth needs placed on
a suicidal, self-harm, or homicidal level, the reason for
the level and the actions to be taken are posted in the
electronic system and the home for staff reference.
• Overnight guests are prohibited at all locations.
• When clients are asleep or outside of the direct supervision
of staff, staff shall perform variable interval, eye-on checks
of residents. The time between the variable interval checks
shall not exceed fifteen minutes.
• Each location has a written work schedule that includes
provisions for use of relief staff, and a back-up plan for
emergencies. in the initial and ongoing staff development
policy.
•
Email from Foster Care Worker dated 9/7/25. I met with The
QRTP placement yesterday and Youth A and safety planned
around these allegations, per policy. The QRTP placement stated
nothing was seen/found on their cameras and they have 24-hour
staff who are present in the hallway outside of the youth’s room all
night. I attempted to speak to Youth A about these allegations.
She only shared that she likes a boy from school. She refused
knowing what kissing is. She stated she leaves her room only with
permission at night. She refused that anyone goes into her
bedroom at night.
Youth A’s overnight visits with parents since school began
on August 25, 2025.
• Overnight visit starting on Friday, August 29th and returning
to the facility on Sunday August 31st.
• Overnight visit starting on Friday, September 5th and
returning to the facility on Sunday September 7th.
5

• Overnight visit starting on Friday, September 12th and
returning to the facility on Sunday September 14th.
Video Review:
A review of the camera footage titled “West hallway to exit” was
completed for the overnight shifts of 8/25/25-8/26/25 and 9/3/25-
9/4/25. At no time was Youth A observed outside of Youth A’s
room until staff woke Youth A for the day. At no time is anyone
other than staff observed going into Youth A’s room or being near
Youth A’s room.
Walk-through:
This is a single-story facility in good repair. It is furnished
appropriately, and all aspects of the facility are in working order.
The camera has a view of the entire hallway with no hidden spots.
Analysis The facility is found in compliance as there is not sufficient
evidence to support the allegations made as evidenced by
interviews with staff, youth, video recording and documents, the
random review of camera footage did not provide any
documentation of youth being in the hallway around Youth A’s
bedroom, but it did support additional findings since staff were not
completing bed checks as required.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4127
Section Staff to resident ratio
Description (4) When residents are asleep or otherwise outside of the direct
supervision of staff, staff shall perform variable interval, eye-on
checks of residents. The time between the variable interval checks
shall not exceed fifteen minutes.
Violation Additional Findings of Non-Compliance
Type
Allegation During this investigation, while observing the video footage of
Youth A’s hallway, it was found staff were not completing required
bed checks during the overnight hours.
Investigation Staff 1 was interviewed face to face at the facility on
9/10/2025. She reported there is always at least one staff
observing the hallway after the youth go to bed at all times. Staff
are sitting in the hallway at one or the other end but can see the
6

entire hallway and all of the bedroom doors. She also reported the
doorways are kept open during the night and staff do room checks
throughout the night according to policy.
Staff 2 was interviewed face to face at the facility on
9/10/2025. She reported if hearing something from a room, she
would get up from the chair that is located close to the middle of
the hallway and walk the hallway looking for the source of the
sound. She reported there is a camera that has footage of the
entire hallway and staff do room checks throughout the night. She
was asked about other duties and reported one staff always stays
in the hallway and the other staff does other duties (cleaning,
laundry, and paperwork).
Staff 3 was interviewed face to face at the facility on
9/10/2025. Her only additions to Staff 2’s report include doing
dishes at night but also reported one staff is always in the hallway.
Administrator was interviewed via video call on 9/18/2025.
She provided a view of the camera footage for 8/26/25 and 9/4/25
during the overnight shift. She reported agreeing staff were not
completing the bed checks per policy and it appeared that there
was a length of over 6 hours that no bed checks were completed
on 8/26/25.
Staff 8 was interviewed via phone on 9/19/2025. He reported
overseeing the camera use at the facility. He reported
Administrator does not have full access to all the items to use
when reviewing the video footage. He reported the cameras begin
recording when sensing movement in the camera view. He will
review the same footage and report back his findings. Staff 8 was
interviewed again via phone on 9/22/2025. He reported
reviewing the same footage and found two additions. The first took
place at 3:14 am (8/26/25) (when the camera picked up some type
of movement, but no staff or youth were viewed in the footage.
The second change with footage at 5:46 am (8/26/25) when a staff
is observed placing hygiene items and towels outside of the
youth’s doorway’s. At no time does the staff conduct a bed check
on any of the youth in the camera footage. He reported it appears
staff were not conducting bed checks as required and there was a
gap of room checks for approximately 6 hours on 8/26/25 between
1:49 am and 6:17 am.
Youth A was interviewed at the school on 9/10/2025. Youth A
reported staff are always in the hallway and keep an eye on Youth
A.
7

Youth D was interviewed video call on 9/26/2025. She reported
staff sit outside of the bedroom and will also walk around the
hallway checking on youth. Youth D also reported getting up to
use the bathroom at night and seeing staff in the hallway.
Youth F was interviewed video call on 9/26/2025. Youth F
reported staff check on Youth F during the night. Youth F reported
letting staff know if Youth F needs to use the bathroom and
reported staff sitting in the hallway at night.
Documents Reviewed:
Genacross Lutheran Services Position Description: Youth
Residential Worker Full time 3rd shift without a date. This
document outlines the duties and responsibilities for staff working
3rd shift at the program. These are listed below:
• Supervise and monitor residents overnight. You must stay
awake while on duty.
• Keep records (shift notes, IR’s, behavioral objectives) on
individual residents, including sleep patterns, daily
observations and information about activities, behaviors
and social interactions with peers.
• Perform direct care functions (assist with ADLs & ensure
resident’s needs are met).
• Log bed checks as required.
• Assist in preparing food for residents and serving meals
and refreshments to residents.
• Provide coping skills, verbally attempt to de-escalate
residents when in crisis. Use approved physical crisis
intervention as a last resort to keep residents and staff
safe.
• Utilize trauma informed treatment approaches in all
interactions with youth following the SAMHSA principles
and domains. Contribute to a positive work environment by
following Genacross’ mission and vision statements.
• Communicate with co-workers and supervisors to help
create safe environment for residents and staff. Provide
information to supervisors, co-workers, and subordinates
by telephone, in written form, e-mail, or in person.
• Assist in keeping work sites clean.
• Report allegations of abuse/neglect to proper organization
leadership and proper authorities.
• Follow all agency policies. Implement and follow all
universal precautions, disaster plans and hazardous
material protocol.
8

• Must meet all physical demand requirements.
• All other duties as assigned.
Genacross Lutheran Services Staffing Requirements and
Supervision dated 11/13/24. This document outlines the required
supervision of youth in the program. The following is the policy:
• Genacross will ensure a minimum staffing ratio of one staff
to two clients occurs during wake hours for any home in the
State of Michigan.
• Genacross will ensure a minimum staffing ratio of two staff
to ten clients during sleeping hours in the State of Michigan.
• Genacross will ensure a minimum staffing ratio of one staff
to ten clients during awake and sleeping hours in the State
in Ohio.
• Childcare staff will provide supervision as specified in the
clients’ service plan. It should be noted that an email
notification is made to all staff should any client be on a level
system due to ongoing concerns.
o If the treatment team determines that a youth needs
placed on a behavioral level, specific parameters are
determined based on the youth and the reason for the
level. Specific supervision guidelines will be posted in
the home for staff to review as well as in our electronic
system. Supervision guidelines will be posted in the
home for staff reference.
o If a clinician determines that a youth needs placed on
a suicidal, self-harm, or homicidal level, the reason for
the level and the actions to be taken are posted in the
electronic system and the home for staff reference.
• Overnight guests are prohibited at all locations.
• When clients are asleep or outside of the direct supervision
of staff, staff shall perform variable interval, eye-on checks
of residents. The time between the variable interval checks
shall not exceed fifteen minutes.
• Each location has a written work schedule that includes
provisions for use of relief staff, and a back-up plan for
emergencies. in the initial and ongoing staff development
policy.
Adrian Group Home Bed Check logs starting on 8/26/25 and
ending on 9/10/25. These logs have all the youth (6 youth) listed
on the log along with time of the check and statues of the youth
(asleep, shower, school, awake, bathroom, and sleep talking) at
9

the time of the check. 68 Bed Checks are documented by staff for
the overnight shifts on 8/26/25 and 9/4/25 as occurring with only 4
(18,19, 20, and 20 minute) documented as occurring outside of
the 15-minute time frame. However, upon review of the camera
footage, there were only 25 bed checks observed, and they
ranged from 3-minutes to 6 hours and 27-minutes between the
checks (see the chart below).
Video Review:
Two days were reviewed 8/26/25 and 9/4/25. The camera view is
the same and titled “West hallway to exit” which covers Youth A’s
room which is located on the left side of the hallway from this
view. Each day’s reviewed camera footage is from 11:00 pm (day
prior to 8/26/25 and 9/4/25) to 7:00 am on 8/26/25 and 9/4/25. It
should also be noted that the video cameras will turn on when
they detect movement in the hallway. This causes the footage to
jump forward when there is no movement.

Comparing bed check logs to video footage:
9/3/25-9/4/25

Analysis The facility is found in non-compliance as there is sufficient
evidence to support staff on third shift not completing bed checks
on youth as required by rule and the facility’s policy. Two
overnight blocks of time were reviewed but during this time there
was a period of time exceeding 6 hours that staff did not check on
the well-being of youth during the overnight hours. Several times
staff would walk by the room without slowing their pace and
glanced into the room rather than checking on the youth. Also,
several times, staff would only look into 1 or 2 bedrooms without
observing youth in all three rooms within the camera view.
TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE:
Technical assistance was offered regarding staff learning to do an
appropriate room check. Staff should be making visual
observations of the youth’s skin and breathing to ensure the youth
is not in distress and present in the room. Glancing into a room
while walking by is not enough to provide appropriate supervision.
Technical Assistance was offered regarding documenting bed
checks. It became apparent that staff during the two nights the
video was reviewed were documenting bed checks being
completed, although insufficient checks or sitting at the end of the
hallway does not constitute bed checks. It was recommended a
system that would provide more accurate accounting of bed
checks is put into place. This could include up to an electronic
wand system or the use of a tablet to record the check.
Technical Assistance was offered regarding administration staff
doing a random inspection of the third shift staff by showing up at
the facility during the overnight hours to observe staff and check
the bed check logs.
Conclusion Violation Established
14

IV. RECOMMENDATION
Based on investigative findings the facility is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it
is recommended that the current license status be continued.
10/10/2025
